steps.title: Identify the Function
steps.body: We need to find the integral of 3x² from 0 to 2. The function f(x) = 3x² is a polynomial function.

steps.title: Find the Antiderivative
steps.body: The antiderivative of 3x² is F(x) = x³ + C. Since we're dealing with a definite integral, the constant C will cancel out.

steps.title: Apply the Fundamental Theorem
steps.body: Using the fundamental theorem: ∫[0,2] 3x² dx = F(2) - F(0) = (2)³ - (0)³ = 8 - 0 = 8

steps.title: Verify the Result
steps.body: We can verify this by taking the derivative of our result: d/dx(x³) = 3x², which matches our original function.

steps.title: Understand the Problem
steps.body: We want to find the derivative of an integral with a variable upper limit. This is a direct application of the second part of the fundamental theorem.

steps.title: Apply the Second Fundamental Theorem
steps.body: If F(x) = ∫[a,x] f(t) dt, then F'(x) = f(x). In our case, f(t) = sin(t²), so F'(x) = sin(x²).

steps.title: Interpret the Result
steps.body: This means that the rate of change of the area under the curve y = sin(t²) from 0 to x is equal to the value of the function at x.

steps.title: Physical Context
steps.body: In physics, work is defined as the integral of force with respect to displacement. This connects directly to the fundamental theorem of calculus.

steps.title: Mathematical Relationship
steps.body: Work = ∫ F(x) dx = ΔPE (change in potential energy). This is a fundamental principle in classical mechanics.

steps.title: Real-World Applications
steps.body: This principle is used in calculating the work done by springs, gravitational forces, and electric fields in physics problems.
